Introduction

Antifungal agents represent approximately 20 individual drugs across 6 classes.  The first half of this article presents the major classes of antifungals, including their mechanisms of action, spectra of activity, major indications, and important adverse effects.  The second half provides a general framework for antifungal selection.

Fungi and antifungals

Fungi



The medically important fungi (

) can be categorized as:



  • Yeasts (eg, Candida, Cryptococcus).
  • Molds (eg, Aspergillus, Mucor, dermatophytes).
  • Dimorphic (mold in environment, yeast in host) (eg, Histoplasma, Blastomyces, Coccidioides).


The distinction between yeasts and molds is relevant primarily for histopathologic identification (eg, observing branching hyphae in molds) but plays a lesser role in antifungal selection.  Instead, the choice of antifungal is guided primarily by the clinical category of infection (eg, skin and superficial infections, systemic and invasive infections), as described later.

Antifungals



Antifungals (

figure 1
) are classified into those that inhibit:



  • Cell wall structure:
    • Inner ergosterol lipid layer (eg, azoles).
    • Outer beta-D-glucan polysaccharide layer (eg, echinocandins).
  • Nucleic acid synthesis (eg, flucytosine).
  • Mitosis (eg, griseofulvin).


In contrast to bacteria, which require different antibiotics based on their gram-positive or gram-negative cell wall structure, all fungi have a similar cell wall composition (although with varying ratios of ergosterol and beta-D-glucan).

Azoles



Azoles (drugs ending in "-azole") inhibit the fungal enzyme lanosterol 14 alpha-demethylase, a critical enzyme in ergosterol (inner lipid layer of cell wall) synthesis.  Therefore, they have broad-spectrum activity against most fungi.  They are subgrouped into topical azoles (imidazoles) and systemic azoles (triazoles).

Topical azoles



Topical azoles (imidazoles) include ketoconazole, clotrimazole, and miconazole.



Because of poor oral bioavailability, they are formulated for topical administration (eg, creams, shampoos) and used primarily for cutaneous fungal infections such as dermatophytoses (eg, tinea pedis, corporis, and capitis), Candida vulvovaginitis, and intertrigo.



Toxicity is uncommon because topical azoles are poorly absorbed through the skin.



(Oral ketoconazole is used as adjunctive therapy for Cushing syndrome because it inhibits endogenous cortisol synthesis; prolonged use can cause adrenal insufficiency.)

Systemic azoles



Systemic azoles (triazoles) include fluconazole, itraconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole.



They have good oral bioavailability and are used for systemic fungal infections, such as endemic mycoses (eg, histoplasmosis, blastomycosis), invasive candidiasis, and pulmonary aspergillosis.



Toxicity is a greater concern with triazoles due to their systemic route of administration.  Major adverse effects include hepatotoxicity (requires routine liver enzyme monitoring), QT-interval prolongation, and drug-drug interactions due to cytochrome P450 inhibition (eg, triazoles increase serum concentrations of warfarin, statins, digoxin, phenytoin, and many other medications).

Echinocandins



The echinocandins (drugs ending in "-fungin") include caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin, and rezafungin.



Echinocandins inhibit the fungal enzyme beta-(1,3)-glucan synthase, a critical enzyme in beta-D-glucan (outer polysaccharide layer of cell wall) synthesis.  Fungal susceptibility to echinocandins is determined by cell wall glucan content:



  • Candida has the highest glucan content.  Echinocandins are the preferred treatment for invasive Candida infections (eg, candidemia).
  • Aspergillus has intermediate beta-D-glucan content, resulting in weaker susceptibility.  Echinocandins are sometimes used as adjunctive therapy for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Non-Candida yeasts (eg, Histoplasma, Cryptococcus) have minimal glucan content.  Echinocandins are generally ineffective.


Echinocandins have minimal toxicity because humans lack a homologue of beta-D-glucan.  The main adverse effect is a transient pruritic infusion reaction due to histamine release.

Polyenes



Polyenes (drugs ending in "-in") include amphotericin B (systemic) and nystatin (topical).



Polyenes are ergosterol disruptors that form pores in the fungal cell membrane.  They are rapidly fungicidal agents because they directly lyse the ergosterol membrane rather than merely inhibiting its synthesis.

Amphotericin B



Amphotericin B has the broadest spectrum of all antifungals and is effective against most pathogenic fungi.  Therefore, it is the drug of choice for the initial treatment of severe invasive infections such as:



  • Cryptococcal meningitis (yeast).
  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (mold).
  • Mucormycosis (mold).
  • Disseminated dimorphic mycosis (eg, disseminated histoplasmosis).


The major adverse effect of amphotericin B is nephrotoxicity.  Amphotericin is excreted in the urine, reaching high concentrations capable of damaging renal tubular epithelial cells.  Nephrotoxicity includes acute kidney injury (due to acute tubular necrosis); metabolic acidosis (due to type 1 distal renal tubular acidosis); electrolyte disturbances such as hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia (due to proximal tubular wasting); and polyuria (due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).  The risk for nephrotoxicity is lower with the liposomal formulation of amphotericin B than with water-soluble formulations (eg, deoxycholate).

Nystatin



Nystatin has minimal systemic absorption and is used mainly as a topical agent for mucocutaneous candidal infections, including:



  • Oral candidiasis (thrush), treated with nystatin liquid elixir ("swish and swallow").
  • Candidal intertrigo (diaper rash), treated with nystatin powder.

Allylamines



Allylamines (drugs ending in "-fine") include terbinafine, naftifine, and butenafine.  They inhibit the fungal squalene epoxidase, a critical enzyme in ergosterol (cell wall lipid) biosynthesis.  Inhibition not only disrupts the cell wall, but also leads to toxic intracellular accumulation of squalene, particularly in keratinocytes and keratin.



Because of the accumulation of squalene in keratin, allylamines exhibit excellent activity against dermatophytic infections, such as tinea (skin) and onychomycosis (nail beds).



Because of its metabolism (eg, by cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver), major adverse effects of terbinafine include hepatotoxicity (requiring periodic monitoring of liver function) and drug-drug interactions (increasing the plasma levels of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, and beta blockers).

Nucleic acid inhibitors



Flucytosine (5-FC) is a pyrimidine analogue that inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by interfering with thymidylate synthase and RNA polymerase, respectively.  Although human cells share this machinery, 5-FC is more selective for fungi, which have higher levels of cytosine transporters.



5-FC is combined with amphotericin B during the initial phases of treatment of 2 conditions:



  • Cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Candida endocarditis.


The amphotericin B permeabilizes the fungal cell wall and enables 5-FC to enter (antifungal synergy).



Major adverse effects include myelosuppression (eg, anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia) and hepatotoxicity.

Microtubule inhibitor



Griseofulvin disrupts fungal cell division by binding to tubulin subunits to block mitotic spindle formation.



Like allylamines, griseofulvin also accumulates in keratin and keratinocytes.  It has excellent activity against dermatophytes and is used for the treatment of tinea and onychomycosis.



Major adverse effects include teratogenicity (pregnancy category X) and hepatotoxicity.

General treatment framework



Although many antifungals have similar spectra of activity and could theoretically be interchanged, their clinical use is limited to specific approved indications.  Antifungal selection is generally guided by the clinical category of infection, which can be classified as either skin and superficial infections or systemic and invasive infections.

Skin and superficial infections

Cutaneous fungal infections



  • Tinea:  Caused by dermatophytes such as Trichophyton spp, Epidermophyton spp, and Microsporum spp.  Dermatophytes infect the stratum corneum and break down keratin.  They cause tinea pedis (athlete's foot), cruris (jock itch), corporis (body ringworm), and capitis (scalp ringworm).  Tinea typically responds well to topical azoles (eg, ketoconazole, clotrimazole).  The azole cream is often combined with a topical corticosteroid (eg, hydrocortisone) to relieve pruritus.  Allylamines (eg, terbinafine) are sometimes used.  Rarely, oral azole (eg, fluconazole) therapy may be required for refractory tinea.
  • Pityriasis versicolor (tinea versicolor):  Caused by Malassezia spp, commensal nondermatophytic fungi that use lipids (eg, skin oil) as a nutrient source.  Patients develop scattered oval hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches with a light silvery scale, often associated with seborrheic dermatitis and dandruff.  Potassium hydroxide scraping characteristically shows a spaghetti-and-meatballs appearance, representing the dimorphic state of round yeast amongst hyphae (mold).  The infection responds to topical azoles (eg, ketoconazole, clotrimazole).  Scalp infections and dandruff can also be treated with medicated shampoo (eg, selenium sulfide, zinc pyrithione).
  • Onychomycosis (tinea unguium):  Caused mainly by dermatophytes and rarely by Candida and molds (eg, Fusarium spp).  Unlike other forms of tinea, onychomycosis responds poorly to topical agents because the fungi are deeply entrenched in the nail matrix.  Therefore, oral terbinafine and oral griseofulvin, which accumulate in keratin, are the regimens of choice; they are typically administered for longer durations (eg, 6 weeks for fingernails, 12 weeks for toenails).

Sporotrichosis



Sporothrix schenckii is an environmental mold that can cause subcutaneous mycosis (nodular and ulcerated lesions tracking along lymphatic channels) when spores are introduced through the skin via minor punctures or lacerations (eg, rose gardeners).  Treatment involves a systemic azole (eg, voriconazole).

Mucocutaneous Candida infections



Noninvasive Candida infections include:



  • Intertrigo:  Usually presents with erythematous plaques and satellite lesions across the inguinal skinfolds, often bilaterally.  Risk factors include obesity, diabetes mellitus, and chronically moist environments (eg, incontinence, diaper rash).  It is typically treated with a topical azole (eg, ketoconazole, clotrimazole) or a topical allylamine (eg, naftifine, butenafine) in addition to local moisture management (eg, antichaffing and drying powders such as talc or zinc oxide).
  • Candida vulvovaginitis:  Usually presents with thick, "cottage cheese" vaginal discharge and is associated with risk factors such as pregnancy, recent antibiotic use, and diabetes mellitus.  It is typically treated with an oral azole (eg, a single dose of fluconazole) or topical azole (eg, miconazole cream).  Candida balanitis (infection of the glans penis beneath the foreskin) is treated similarly.
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush):  Usually presents with oral discomfort, creamy white plaques, and underlying mucosal inflammation (eg, erythema, bleeding) when scraped.  It is typically treated with a liquid nystatin suspension ("swish and swallow") or topical azole (eg, clotrimazole lozenge).  For severe thrush, oral azole treatment is sometimes necessary.  Underlying risk factors (eg, poor corticosteroid inhaler technique) should be addressed.
  • Candida esophagitis:  Usually presents with dysphagia, substernal discomfort, and anorexia.  It occurs in patients with significant cellular immunocompromise (eg, HIV with CD4+ cell count <100/mm3).  Patients usually have concurrent thrush.  Candida esophagitis is treated with systemic azole therapy (eg, fluconazole).

Systemic or invasive fungal infections

Invasive Candida infections (candidemia)



Candidemia represents the spread of Candida beyond mucosal and cutaneous barriers.  Risk factors include critical illness, indwelling vascular catheters, and total parenteral nutrition (especially with high lipid content).  Hematogenous dissemination can seed multiple tissues such as vitreous humor, cardiac valves, and bone.  Empiric treatment involves an echinocandin (eg, intravenous micafungin), which is effective given the high glucan content of Candida, until azole susceptibility can be confirmed.



In addition, infected sites often require specialized management:



  • Candida endophthalmitis requires systemic azole therapy because echinocandins have poor ocular penetration.  Intravitreal amphotericin B or vitrectomy is often required for source control.
  • Candida endocarditis requires prolonged antifungal therapy (eg, high-dose echinocandin or amphotericin B plus 5-FC).  Surgical valve resection is usually required for source control.


Indwelling vascular catheters should be removed, followed by a "line holiday" (eg, no new catheters until blood cultures clear) if possible.

Systemic dimorphic mycoses



The systemic dimorphic mycoses (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) include histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, coccidioidomycosis, and paracoccidioidomycosis.  They cause an acute febrile pulmonary syndrome (fungal pneumonia) with potential extrapulmonary involvement (eg, skin lesions, meningitis).  Treatment typically involves a systemic azole (itraconazole preferred) and, potentially, amphotericin B for disseminated infection.  Echinocandins are not effective, given that these non-Candida yeasts have minimal glucan content.

Aspergillosis



Aspergillus causes 4 distinct conditions:



  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (refractory asthma, bronchiectasis, high IgE) is treated with a systemic azole (eg, voriconazole or itraconazole) to reduce spore burden and systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) to reduce allergic inflammation.
  • Aspergillomas (fungus balls within preexisting lung cavities) are usually asymptomatic and do not require treatment.
  • Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (slowly enlarging nodules, cavities, or fibrotic areas) is difficult to cure but can be suppressed with a systemic azole taken for several years.
  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (necrotizing pneumonia with hemoptysis) is treated with a systemic azole and possible surgical resection of bleeding lobes.

Mucormycosis



The Mucorales order (eg, Mucor and Rhizopus spp) are aggressive molds with angioinvasive hyphae that cause tissue necrosis.  They proliferate rapidly in patients with severe immunocompromise or diabetic ketoacidosis.  Rhinoorbitocerebral disease is the most common manifestation, causing erosion through the sinuses into the frontal lobe.  Treatment involves extensive surgical debridement, initial amphotericin B, and a step-down to an azole (eg, isavuconazole or posaconazole).

Cryptococcosis



Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii can cause meningitis in patients who are profoundly immunocompromised (eg, HIV with CD4+ cell count <100/mm3).  The yeast also disseminates to the lungs, producing severe pneumonia that often progresses to acute respiratory distress syndrome.  Treatment involves amphotericin B, usually with 5-FC for synergy.  Most patients require long-term suppression with a systemic azole (eg, fluconazole).

Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP)



Pneumocystis jiroveci is a quasi-yeast that can cause opportunistic pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts (eg, HIV with CD4+ cell count <200/mm3, organ transplant recipients).  PJP cannot be treated with standard antifungals because P jiroveci does not synthesize ergosterol or glucan.  Instead, PJP is treated with other antimicrobials, including antibiotics (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) and/or antiprotozoal drugs (eg, pentamidine, atovaquone)

Special considerations

Azole resistance



Azoles are the frontline antifungal agent for most infections.  However, rates of azole resistance in Candida have increased significantly (from 0% to 20% in 20 years).  Resistance is driven by various mechanisms, such as azole binding site mutations in lanosterol 14 alpha-demethylase and expression of drug efflux pumps (

figure 2
).  Prolific use of broad-spectrum antibiotics (eg, intensive care units) also fosters Candida overgrowth in general, contributing to resistance.  Resistance is especially problematic in nonâ€“C albicans species (eg, Candida glabrata, Candida krusei), which cause over one-third of all candidal infections in the hospital setting.



Typically, treatment requires switching to a different antifungal class (eg, echinocandin).  Treatment options for C auris, a highly resistant species now considered a critical priority pathogen by the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, may be limited to novel antifungals (eg, ibrexafungerp).

Pregnancy and breastfeeding



Antifungal therapy is relatively limited in pregnancy:



  • Safe:  All topical antifungals are safe due to minimal systemic absorption.  Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for serious infections.
  • Indeterminate:  Systemic azoles demonstrate dose-dependent teratogenicity, but low-dose fluconazole is an acceptable option for more significant infections.  The safety profile of echinocandins is undetermined (pregnancy category C).
  • Contraindicated:  Most systemic azoles (especially during first trimester), terbinafine, and griseofulvin cause definite fetal harm and should be avoided.

Summary



The main classes of antifungal drugs can be categorized by their mechanism of action.  Azoles (eg, fluconazole), allylamines (eg, terbinafine), and polyenes (eg, amphotericin B) target cell wall ergosterol; echinocandins (eg, micafungin) target cell wall beta-D-glucan; flucytosine blocks nucleic acid synthesis; and griseofulvin inhibits microtubules.  Antifungal selection is based on the suspected pathogen involved in the site and type of infection.  Azoles and amphotericin B have the broadest spectrum and are used for wide indications, ranging from cutaneous dermatophyte infections to systemic mycoses.  Echinocandins are used mainly for invasive candidiasis.  Allylamines and griseofulvin are excellent for onychomycosis because they accumulate in keratin.  Hepatotoxicity and drug-drug interactions are a concern for most systemic antifungals, and nephrotoxicity is the main adverse effect of amphotericin B.
